nodes.name: VectorIndexer
nodes.description: Vector Indexer indexes categorical features inside of a Vector. It decides which features are categorical and converts them to category indices. The decision is based on the number of distinct values of a feature.

fields.name: maxCategories
fields.title: Maximum Categories
fields.description: Threshold for the number of values a categorical feature can take. If a feature is found to have > maxCategories values, then it is declared continuous. Must be >= 2

nodes.name: Split 80-20
nodes.description: This node splits the incoming DataFrame into 2. It takes in the fraction to use in splitting the data. For example, if the fraction is .7, it would split the data into 2 DataFrames, one containing 70% of the rows(passed from lower edge id to next node) and the other containing the remaining 30%(passed from higher edge id to next node).

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: fraction1
fields.title: Fraction 1
fields.description: Fraction to be used for Splitting the DataFrame into two. The first DataFrame would go to the lower edge output. The other would go to the higher edge output.

fields.title: Impurity
fields.description: The Criterion used for information gain calculation

fields.title: Loss Function
fields.description: The Loss function which GBT tries to minimize

fields.name: maxBins
fields.title: Max Bins
fields.description: The maximum number of bins used for discretizing continuous features.Must be >= 2 and >= number of categories in any categorical feature.

fields.name: maxDepth
fields.title: Max Depth
fields.description: The Maximum depth of a tree

fields.name: maxIter
fields.title: Max Iterations
fields.description: The maximum number of iterations(>=0)(a.k.a numtrees)

fields.name: minInfoGain
fields.title: Min Information Gain
fields.description: The Minimum information gain for a split to be considered at a tree node

fields.name: minInstancesPerNode
fields.title: Min Instances Per Node
fields.description: The Minimum number of instances each child must have after split

fields.name: subsamplingRate
fields.title: Subsampling Rate
fields.description: The fraction of the training data used for learning each decision tree.

fields.name: seed
fields.title: Seed
fields.description: The random seed

fields.name: stepSize
fields.title: Step Size
fields.description: Step size (a.k.a. learning rate), The step size to be used for each iteration of optimization.

fields.name: cacheNodeIds
fields.title: Cache Node Ids
fields.description: The caching nodes IDs. Can speed up training of deeper trees.

fields.name: checkpointInterval
fields.title: Checkpoint Interval
fields.description: The checkpoint interval. E.g. 10 means that the cache will get checkpointed every 10 iterations.Set checkpoint interval (>= 1) or disable checkpoint (-1)

fields.name: maxMemoryInMB
fields.title: Max memory
fields.description: Maximum memory in MB allocated to histogram aggregation.

fields.name: validationIndicatorCol
fields.title: Validation Indicator Column
fields.description: Param for name of the column that indicates whether each row is for training or for validation.

fields.name: featureSubsetStrategy
fields.title: Feature Subset Strategy
fields.description: The number of features to consider for splits at each tree node

fields.name: minWeightFractionPerNode
fields.title: Min Weight Fraction per Node
fields.description: Minimum fraction of the weighted sample count that each child must have after split.

fields.name: weightCol
fields.title: Weight Column
fields.description: Param for weight column name. If this is not set or empty, we treat all instance weights as 1.0.

fields.name: comment
fields.value:
Analyzing a bike sharing dataset


This workflow creates an GBT Regression model for predicting the number of bikes to be rented in any given day and hour. - Click note for more info


Data


The dataset contains bike rental info from 2011 and 2012 in the Capital bikeshare system, plus additional relevant information such as weather. This dataset is from Fanaee-T and Gama (2013) and is hosted by the UCI Machine Learning Repository.



Goal


We want to learn to predict bike rental counts (per hour) from information such as day of the week, weather, season, etc. Having good predictions of customer demand allows a business or service to prepare and increase supply as needed.



Load and understand the data


We begin by loading our data, which is stored in Comma-Separated Value (CSV) format. For that, we use the CSV node from SparkFlows, which creates a Spark DataFrame containing the dataset.



Data description


  • From the UCI ML Repository description, we know that the columns have the following meanings.
  • Feature columns:
  • datetime : timestamp
  • season: season (1:spring, 2:summer, 3:fall, 4:winter)
  • holiday: whether day is holiday or not
  • workingday: if day is neither weekend nor holiday is 1, otherwise is 0.


  • temp: Normalized temperature in Celsius. The values are derived via (t-t_min)/(t_max-t_min), t_min=-8, t_max=+39 (only in hourly scale)
  • atemp: Normalized feeling temperature in Celsius. The values are derived via (t-t_min)/(t_max-t_min), t_min=-16, t_max=+50 (only in hourly scale)
  • humidity: Normalized humidity. The values are divided to 100 (max)
  • windspeed: Normalized wind speed. The values are divided to 67 (max)



Label columns:


  • casual: count of casual users
  • registered: count of registered users
  • cnt: count of total rental bikes including both casual and registered



Workflow


  • Preprocess the data
  • Extract year, month, day of month and hour from datetime field useing DateTimeFieldExtract Node.
  • Cast the cunt field type to double.


Feature assembler and indexer


  • Assemble feature columns into a feature vector.
  • Identify categorical features, and index them.


Split data into training and test sets


  • Our final data preparation step will split our dataset into separate training and test sets. We can train and tune our model as much as we like on the training set, as long as we do not look at the test set. After we have a good model (based on the training set), we can validate it on the held-out test set in order to know with high confidence our well our model will make predictions on future (unseen) data.


Visualize our data


  • Now that we have preprocessed our features and prepared a training dataset, we can quickly visualize our data to get a sense of whether the features are meaningful.
  • In the plot, we compare bike rental counts versus hour of the day. As one might expect, rentals are low during the night, and they peak in the morning (8am) and in the early evening (6pm).
